item.title: Sync Forked Repository With Upstream ğŸ”âœ”ï¸
item.description: Here’s the situation, You have forked a repository on GitHub, you have made your changes and sent a pull request, and that request has been merged. Now you want to make further changes, but the repository mentions that you are X commits ahead or/and X commits behind upstream repository. So how do you sync it? You can delete your fork and fork the original repository again, but that is a very tedious thing to do.

item.description: Here’s a common scenario, You have committed a file to your git repo and have also pushed to remote. The file wasn’t supposed to be there, maybe it was something you forgot to mention in your gitignore or something that was supposed to be an environment variable, or maybe it was a binary not related to the project at all ( Cat GIFs? ğŸ˜‰). This not only raises some security concerns but also drives the size of your repository up and simply deleting the file won’t fix the problem.
